awd_titl_txt: Evaluating the Role of Fluid and Melts in Mediating Element Recycling and Exhumation During Retrograde Metamorphism Following UHP Metamorphism
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract
Plate tectonics introduces a feedback loop in which subduction of crustal material at convergent plate margins continually injects less dense rocks formed at the surface back into Earth's dense mantle. As this crustal material is subducted, it interacts with the mantle, exchanges elements, and continuously drives the geochemical evolution of Earth. In order to determine the effect of element recycling during the exhumation of subducted rocks, it is necessary to investigate the chemical reactions that occur during the exhumation of crustal rocks back to Earth's surface. Ultrahigh-pressure (UHP) terranes contain rocks that were carried down to mantle depths via subduction and then returned to the surface. Some of the rocks within UHP terranes preserve "pristine" mineral assemblages that equilibrated at mantle depths. Typically the outermost rind of these rocks contain new or "retrogressed" mineral assemblages that formed as the rocks were being exhumed to the surface. By comparing the chemistry of the "fresh" to the "retrogressed" UHP rocks, the chemical changes that are triggered by exhumation will be examined and their impact upon the geochemical evolution of Earth will be assessed.

Technical Abstract
Mass transfer within subduction zones remains poorly understood. In particular, there is limited knowledge of the P-T conditions at which elemental recycling occurs and of what transporting agents drive the elemental-recycling processes. Many field-based studies have focused upon exhumed high-pressure and ultrahigh-pressure (UHP) terranes to better understand the devolatilization reactions and products that occur along the prograde path as crustal rocks are subducted deep within Earth. In contrast, the retrograde reactions that transpire during the exhumation of these deeply subducted rocks have largely been ignored despite the fact that peak temperatures generally occur along the retrograde path and devolatilization and melting reactions are common. Retrograde metamorphic reactions and associated mass transfer may thus have a great influence on elemental-recycling processes in subduction zones and may also dictate the nature of the exhumation processes that bring crustal material from UHP depths to the surface. This integrated field and laboratory study of the Western Gneiss Region will reveal whether large-scale elemental recycling occurs during retrogression of UHP crustal rocks and whether these processes influence the rates and mechanisms by which UHP terranes are exhumed back to Earth's surface.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Mass transfer within subduction zones, where rocks that are part of the crust are taken to great depths in the Earth, remains poorly understood. This mass transfer has important implications for how the Earth has evolved into its different chemical layers, and on a smaller scale, this mass transfer influences the composition of arc magmas and new continental crust.  Many studies have focused upon areas on Earth where rocks that were subducted to great depths have been brought back to the surface. These rocks preserve a record of the processes occurring in subduction zones. Previous studies have mainly focused on the reactions that occur in the rocks as they have been subducted. Fewer studies have investigated how elements are transferred during reactions that are occurring as the rocks are exhumed to the surface.  The Western Gneiss Region, Norway, is a large area that preserves these rocks that have been subducted and exhumed. Specifically, mafic rocks that best preserve evidence of the subduction history are found as pods within abundant rock rich in quartz and plagioclase called gneiss. Chemical data from the rocks and the individual minerals within these rocks indicate that multiple fluid sources are mobilized during exhumation, and these fluids affect different parts of the pods. The cores of the mafic pods are affected by internal fluids sourced from the mafic rock itself or from veins and/or inclusions of other rock types within the pod. The exterior of the pods are variably affected by fluids sourced external from the pod, likely from the host gneiss. These fluids are very effective at element redistribution, significantly increasing the fluid-mobile element content in the rims of the mafic pods. The results also show that at greater depths in the subduction channel and under higher strain, element mobility is more efficient, and external fluids permeate farther into the mafic pods. Finally, the results show clear evidence that mineral breakdown reactions occurring as these rocks are exhumed to the surface drives significant fluid-mediated element redistribution following subduction.

 

Broader Impacts

This grant has supported the education and training of one postdoctoral fellow and several graduate students. The postdoc was closely mentored in analytical research activities. The postdoc and graduate students were also mentored in outreach activities that involved giving geoscience lessons to 7th and 8th graders. These middle-schoolers were on the UNR campus as part of a university-wide outreach program targeting first-generation, low-income students. The PI, postdoc, and graduate students gave multiple lessons on the rock cycle, the timing of geologic events, and subduction zone processes to the students. The team worked with the coordinators of the on-campus program to ensure that the lessons were at the right level and that they engaged the students. In addition, there was significant collaboration with outside laboratories and scientists, including those at University of Western Australia, Curtin University, Stanford University, and UC-Santa Barbara. The results from this grant have been published in one international peer-reviewed journal, with one additional article under review, and in multiple presentations by the PI and the postdoc at professional meetings.

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2021
Modified by: Stacia Gordon
